turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Polk County et al. against Russell Richard Dodson.
Mr. Jesse, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, this proceeding arose out of a pro se complaint filed by the Respondent under 42 USC 1983 in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa, November 5th, 1979.

That complaint alleged various claims against the Petitioner Martha Shepard in the Polk County Offender Advocate's office against the Polk County Board of Supervisors and against the entity of Polk County.

Respondent alleged that Petitioner Shepard had failed to properly represent him on appeal of his conviction for first degree robbery in the District Court of Iowa in and for Polk County to the Iowa Supreme Court.

He claimed that her actions in failing to... in failing to represent him properly in that... in that appeal had deprived him of his right to counsel under the Sixth Amendment, and imposed upon him cruel and unusual punishment, and had arbitrarily denied him his state-created right to appeal to the Iowa Supreme Court from its conviction.
He also asserted claims for... for legal malpractice and for breach of an oral contract to prosecute the appeal to the Supreme Court.
The Polk County Offender Advocate was also named.

The Board of Supervisors of Polk County and Polk County itself were named, alleging that they were responsible for Ms. Shepard's action because they had adopted established rules and procedures for handling such appeals.
His complaint sought injunctive relief.
It is of monetary damages and release from confinement.

The District Court dismissed the complaint, ruling that Petitioner Shepard and the Offender Advocate did not act under color of state law, that the complaint did not allege the requisite personal involvement of the Polk County... members of the Polk County Board of Supervisors, or of the Polk County Offender Advocate.
It construed his request for... for release to be a petition for habeas corpus, and found that he had not exhausted his state remedies, and therefore dismissed that as well.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the decision of the District Court, finding that the county employed the public defender, and that a county... county employed public defender does act under color of state law, because the public defender in that situation is selected, paid, hired and fired by the county, that the public defenders have their power because of the fact that they are employed to represent indigent defendants, and not because they have been selected by the defendants for whom they are providing representation.

Having decided that the county employed public defender is... is involved in state action, then the Court of Appeals ruled that the county employed public defender enjoys only a qualified immunity, and further, that as a matter of pleading, that the Respondent had stated a 1983 claim against the Board of Supervisors and the Offender Advocate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did the Eighth Circuit intimate any view as to whether a non-indigent defendant suing his privately licensed counsel whom he had chosen would be liable under 1983 because the state had licensed him as a member of the Bar?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: No, I don't believe the Court indicated that they would intend any such result.
I don't believe that question was discussed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think that would follow fairly naturally from this whole thing?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: That is not the law, as I understand it.
It seems to me that it would--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I never understood it to be the law, either, but I have never understood the Eighth Circuit's holding to be the law.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Well, I agree with Your Honor that that would seem to be a logical extension from the finding that because they are county employed and have not been selected, that they are involved in state action.
By the same rationale you could say that the license provided to practice law was state action sufficient to make a privately employed counsel amenable to suit.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Subject to suit for his actions.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: I do not agree that that is the law, and we are contending otherwise.

Petitioner petitioned this Court for a writ of certiorari, presenting two questions, and that is whether the Court of Appeals erred in holding the county employed public defender acts under color of state law in representing indigent defendants, and is thus amenable to suit under 42 USC 1983, and two, whether the Court of Appeals erred in holding that in suits brought under 42 USC 1983 a county employed public defender enjoys only a qualified immunity from suit for his actions taken while representing indigent clients.
This Court granted cert March 2, 1981.

The Court is favored here with amicus briefs by the United States, by the National Legal Aid and Defenders Association, by the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, and by the Minnesota State Public Defender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought the Court of Appeals indicated that a private attorney appointed by the state wouldn't act under color of state law, and certainly if that were true, a private... an attorney employed privately wouldn't, either, would he?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: I would think that a private attorney employed by a defendant would not be amenable to suit under 1983.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And didn't the Court of Appeals say so?

At least... don't they have authority in the Eighth Circuit to the effect that an appointed attorney, a private attorney appointed by the Court to represent an indigent defendant does not act under color of state law?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: There is such authority in the Eighth District and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In the Eighth Circuit.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Or in the Eighth Circuit, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I would suppose... wouldn't it be a fortiori that a private attorney wouldn't be subject to a 1983?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Certainly it would be difficult to have those inconsistent results of a private attorney amenable to suit and a court-appointed attorney not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about the prosecutor?
Is he subject?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: No, the prosecutor has absolute immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He has got absolute liability.
How about the judge?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: The judge has absolute immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In what respect does a public defender serving in this capacity as part of one of the three legs of the stool, the judge, the prosecutor, the defense counsel, in what respect is he different from the others in performing the broad social function and constitutional function of providing counsel?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, it is our contention that he is not functioning in that capacity, that he is not essentially different than the... in terms of the public policy ramifications, than is the prosecutor or the judge.
However, in a very limited context, this Court has, in Ferri versus Ackerman, decided that he is not a part of a tri-partite equal person for purposes of applying--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That was in a malpractice suit, was it not?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --That's correct.
In a state t malpractice suit, that the Court would not apply a Federal absolute immunity to that situation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't the real difference that he represents the defendant, period, and nobody else?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: That's correct, and that is our position, that the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that is the difference.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --that the public defender is really analogous to court-appointed counsel, court-appointed private counsel, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But is he required to be?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --I think that he is required to be by both the canons of ethics by his responsibilities as a lawyer, to be... to owe his sole obligation and his sole-his sole work for the benefit of the defendant.
The fact that he is employed as a public defender and is paid by the county is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He is not really employed.
He is paid by the state.
He is not employed by the state.
Isn't there a difference there?
I mean, when somebody is employed by somebody, he is under the control of that person, but is the defender here under the control of the state at all, once he is appointed?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --I believe not.

He is not under the control of the Board of Supervisors of Polk County in any respect as it relates to his handling of his client's case, and the responsibilities and obligations that he owes to his client.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is he in any difference posture professionally... I emphasize professionally... from a psychiatrist at the state mental hospital for indigents, or a surgeon at a hospital provided... which provides services for indigents?
In each case, he is to function as a professional carrying out his professional duty.
Is that not right?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: There is a sense in which that is true, yes, and the Respondents--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In what sense is it not true?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --and the United States have cited cases which would analogize the situation of the professional relationship between the attorney and his indigent client, and a medical director of a state mental health institute or some similar facility.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, we have held in O'Connor have we not, that the medical director of a mental hospital does... the state action requirement under 1983 is satisfied, haven't we?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know you haven't cited O'Connor in your briefs, or in your reply brief, but Respondent relies on it rather heavily.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Right, Respondent--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But didn't we hold that in O'Connor add Donaldson?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --The state action question was not... was not precisely addressed in O'Connor but that mainly turned on the cruel and inhuman punishment feature.
It assumed, however, state action, and the difference--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, we did, we certainly did, and we allowed liability, didn't we?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --You allowed liability, and so--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under 1983.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --so state action is assumed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under 1983.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what is the difference between a doctor-patient relationship and the attorney-client i relationship?
Is there any?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: There is no difference, but you need to look further than just whether or not that professional relationship existed between the patient and the medical director, and whether or not that is different than the position of an attorney, a public defender and his indigent defendant, and there is a difference.

The difference is that the medical director of a state mental health institute is performing both a medical function for which he has a relationship and providing for another state interest which is providing for the housing and confinement of persons and treatment of persons with mental illness.
So there is another--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, can't you say the same thing here, that a public defender is satisfying the state's obligation to protect indigents?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --The public defender is satisfying the public interest that is imposed upon them by Gideon versus Wainwright and the cases construing the right to counsel, and the requirement that the state provide effective assistance of counsel.

However, when you look at the activity of the lawyer involved, it is clear that he represents an interest that is contrary to the state's real interest, and that is the prosecution and confinement of persons who are convicted of crime.
That is the state's interest.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But when a psychiatrist in a state hospital examines a defendant who is charged with a crime, he may be performing functions which in the end result are directly contrary to the prosecutor's, the state's right as asserted by the prosecutor to convict him, because the psychiatrist may come out with the conclusion that he is incapable of forming the necessary intent, and therefore in effect not guilty by reason of insanity.
Is there any difference between that conflict and the attorney's conflict with the prosecutor in the adversary system?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, that is true in the adversary context, except that the... except that the... it would be very difficult when you have a state institution that without question deprives a person of his liberty and a person functioning within that institution who has the medical relationship between the client, it would be very difficult to say that that person who is directing that institution that confines the person was not engaged in state conduct, and that is not related to the function, the medical function that is being performed by that individual.
It has to do with the unquestioned state action of depriving the person of liberty, and the maintenance of that institution, state institution for that purpose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, one of the key figures in that process that you have described, denying him his liberty, is the prosecutor, and we extend to the prosecutor an absolute immunity.
This goes back to my earlier question to you.
In broad social and constitutional terms, how is the defense counsel performing any different function from the prosecutor?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, we would argue that the prosecutor, or that the defense attorney really performs in the broad social sense the same kind of functions--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And constitutional sense.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --and ought to be accorded the same kind of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Also a constitutional sense, under Gideon and Argensinger.
Is that not so?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Yes.
Yes, because he is providing the necessary ingredient of providing the effective assistance of counsel.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Each is engaged in administering justice, each with a different role.
Is that not so?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: That is correct.

The prosecution and the... the prosecutor is involved in the prosecution of persons who are accused of crime, and that is part of the state function that is his responsibility, and the public defender is involved in providing that other essential ingredient for a valid conviction, which is in the state's interest, and that is the effective assistance of counsel.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, in that respect, the appointed counsel or the retained one doesn't differ, does he, from the public defender?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: No, we would argue that they are not essentially different, and that if, as the Eighth Circuit has ruled in this case, if a public defender whose only real relationship to the state is that he receives his paycheck from the state is amenable to 1983 suits, that a court-appointed attorney would... who performs essentially the same services and is paid from the very same pot of money is paid from the very same levy as the public defender.
And as it happens in Polk County, the Board of Supervisors of Polk County have in operation a dual system of providing for counsel.
They have the defender advocates program, which is a county program, paid for out of the court fund, and they have a parallel system of court-appointed private attorneys.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And they treat them separately, apparently, for purposes of 1983.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, we maintain that you should not treat them separately, but the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know, but the Court of Appeals would treat them separately.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --the Court of Appeals would treat them separately.
We maintain that there is no essential difference between a court-appointed private attorney who is Paid out of the court fund and a public defender who is paid for out of the court fund.
The state is involved in the determination of indigency in both cases, and it is the same... the same determination of what indigency is as it applies to a particular defendant.

The court makes the appointment in the one case or in the other, and all the... all the county has done as a practical matter, all the county has done is to organize a group of attorneys into one office, where theoretically they can be provided with better library facilities and better secretarial services, and can be provided an investigator, and the capacity to provide effective assistance of counsel, and rather than paying a higher per hour or higher per unit cost to a private attorney who must provide his own library and his own secretary and his own investigative services.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Jesse, this Court hasn't really decided, though, has it, whether Court-appointed private counsel are said to be acting under color of state law for purposes of Section 1983.
The Ferri case really didn't decide that, did it?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: No, it did not, and this Court has not addressed directly that question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Also, how do you get around such cases as Burton versus Wilmington Parking Authority in deciding when the state, and in this case the county, or a county official, or a public defender is acting under color of state law, where a private restaurant was held to be acting under color of state law simply because it had leased the space from the state?
That was sufficient.
Now, how do you get around cases like that?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, but the state, it was leasing the facility from the state, and the state was involved in a parallel operation with the restaurant owner, and presumably they... both parties benefitted from that relationship.
The restaurant operator benefitted from the parking facilities that were available, and the presence of the parking facilities benefitted the restaurant owner by the presence of customers.

That is quite a different relationship than the... than the Board of Supervisors has with the offender advocate program in Polk County, and we believe that what you need to look at is the... is the action that is complained about, the action that is complained about, and not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Apply a function test, in other words,--

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Well, I believe that the Court has already in a sense applied a kind of function test in Branti versus Finkel, where state action was found with respect to the public defenders program, but it was found in the context of the public defender terminating the employment of certain persons who worked for him.
Now, that is clearly and unmistakably the exercise of a power that is conferred by the statute.
On the other hand, the public defender, the individual public defender, who might be amenable to suit under the Eighth Circuit's theory of this case, does not exercise that power.

That person exercises the power that any attorney has, and that power only, and the fact of the creation of the public defender's office does not enhance the powers that are exercised, or enhance the activities that the public... assistant public defender is involved in.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Mr. Jesse, is the prosecutor of Polk County elected?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, he is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, the lawyer is appointed by the court or the supervisors?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: The Board of Supervisors appoints the offender advocate in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To each case?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: No, to... no, they appoint the offender advocate, and the offender advocate has several assistants that he appoints.
The Board of Supervisors approves their appointments and sets their salary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I come before the judge, and the judge says, I'm going to appoint you a lawyer.
Who does he appoint?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: He appoints the offender advocate's office.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Office.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Or, a person from the assigned counsel list.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Committed.
It is sort of a committee?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, they maintain a list of persons who have agreed to accept appointments.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the supervisors pay him.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: The supervisors pay both.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The supervisors pay each lawyer, or the office?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: The supervisors create a budget for the Office of Offender Advocate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And they get paid by the year?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: And they are on annual salaries.
They are prohibited from engaging in private... in other private practice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You see, you are now giving me trouble about his individual responsibility to the individual client when he is being paid by the year.
That gives me a little problem.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Well, but if he--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Doesn't it give you a little problem?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --I believe that there is no essential difference.

The structure of the offender advocate program is merely a why of collecting together the persons who are providing those services to indigent defendants, hopefully provide them with better facilities, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Don't you see a difference between the judge saying, I will appoint Lawyer Jones to defend you, and the judge saying, I will give you an office to defend you?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --But the effect is exactly the same, because Lawyer Jones has to have an office, and the judge is, when he approves that fee, is paying part of his rent and part of his telephone and part of his secretary and part of his library.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, who does the defendant look to for service, the office or an individual?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: To the individual.
Every case is assigned by the offender advocate to an individual lawyer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But not the Court.
But the Court does not give him a lawyer.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: The Court does not select from among the lawyers in the Offender Advocate's Office.
There are nine lawyers, and the Court does not select.
He appoints the offender advocate to be the person, and the offender advocate delegates the responsibility to the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I still have a problem.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Well, this presents a public policy argument that... that is involved in the Eighth Circuit's decision, and that is that rather than enhancing the t capability of the county to provide indigent services, provide representation of indigents through the creation of offender advocates programs or public defenders, they will abandon those and go to a total system of assigned counsel on an appointment basis of private attorneys in order to avoid the exposure to 1983 actions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, we haven't even decided that, have we?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: You have not yet decided that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Jesse, may I ask--
--Well, if you decided you were in trouble now, you might be in trouble then, under the other system, too.
And isn't it true that if we decide, if we agree with you on the color of law question, that we need not reach the amenity issue at all?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: That's correct, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Jesse, when the District Judge dismissed this complaint, as I understand the papers, he forwarded the papers to the Iowa Supreme Court, to give them an opportunity to hear the appeal on the merits, which counsel thought was without merit.
Do you know if the Iowa Supreme Court ever did decide the appeal on the merits?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: I think that the Iowa Supreme Court did not decide the case on the merits.
The case was disposed of under Rule 104, which provides for the dismissal of frivolous appeals, and the Court did, pursuant to the motion of Mrs. Shepard, dismiss that case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then in this case the District Judge says, after everything was done, he forwarded everything to the Chief Justice of the Iowa Supreme Court, and nothing further happened as far as we know, then.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Not to my knowledge.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Hudson?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I agree with Justice Marshal that the place to begin the analysis of this case is with an examination of the relevant statute under which the Public Defender's Office was created.
In Iowa, we have an Iowa Public Defender Act which is found at Chapter 336(A) of the Iowa Code.
Under this particular statute, the county supervisors of a particular county or group of counties if they so choose can decide by resolution to form a Public Defender's Office.
The office is created by the supervisors.
They determine a budget for the supervisors.

They ask the district judges of the county to nominate certain individuals who would be well qualified to serve as a public defender, and the county supervisors select the individual from that particular list.

The county supervisors are given the responsibility of defining the term "indigency", which thus gives them the power to decide which individuals will be eligible for representation by the public defender.

In addition to this... these responsibilities, it is the responsibility of the public defender to submit an annual report to the Attorney General of the State of Iowa, to the chief judge of the judicial district in which he practices, and also to the county supervisors.
The supervisors are given the opportunity of terminating the office at any time that they deem appropriate.

It seems clear, and it was acknowledged by the Eighth Circuit that this, the extensive involvement of the local county supervisors in the Public Defender Office means that the public defender himself and his or her assistants become inextricably linked to the political process.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Hudson, is this the ground on which you distinguish, or do you distinguish from the appointed counsel?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I do distinguish on this ground.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On this ground?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see, but your submission also is that the appointed counsel, there would be no state action involved?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I agree with Mr. Jesse.
I believe the case in the Eighth Circuit is Barnes versus Dorsey.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: And that particular case presently holds that appointed private counsel does not act under color of law.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: My question really is, do you agree with that decision?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Your Honor, the Court in its last term, in the case of Cuyler versus Sullivan, has placed the holdings of those cases in jeopardy, it seems to me.

In that particular case, they state criminal trial was found to be an action by the state, and a privately retained counsel who offered ineffective service to his client in that case was found to be denial of due process.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that issue is still open, you suggest.
Well, wasn't the reasoning of the Court there that the prisoner was held by a judgment of the state mandated by the court?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: In Cuyler, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In Cuyler, yes.
Not that his particular attorney had performed incompetently.
Or that his attorney acted under color of law.
Those are different concepts, aren't they?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: The color of law question was certainly not raised in Cuyler versus Sullivan.

The question there was whether or not a privately retained attorney could offer ineffective assistance of counsel to the extent that the trial became a meaningful charade... meaningless charade, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, and it was held there was sufficient state action to set aside the conviction?
Right?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --So this Court held, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.
Well, in any event, Mr. Hudson, you don't have to concede, and you don't, I gather--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I do not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --the answer to whether or not the privately appointed counsel involves state action.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I would concede that to my knowledge every circuit court has so held, that the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That it does not involve state action.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --that it does not involve state action.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the holding is that the private attorney doesn't act under color of law, under color of state law.
That is the way--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: The Eighth Circuit has so held, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Yes.
It isn't a question of state action.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Very well, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you have referred to the extensive regulation of the Polk County public defender.
Certainly the Iowa bar extensively regulates the members of the Iowa bar, does it not?
Even though they might be privately retained to defend a criminal in an action?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Well, of course, we are all subject to the same ethical considerations, Your Honor, and we are all subject to the same rules and regulations governing the profession of the practice of law.
The regulation that I am talking about that Polk County imposes upon the public defender is, in particular, money.
They have the opportunity to define indigency.
It is conceivable, at least under the Iowa statute, that they could go so far as to say that indigency shall include anyone who makes less than $30,000 a year, so--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, doesn't the Iowa bar have the right to define champerty, and maintenance, and all sorts of other things that bar associations traditionally define as violations of canons of ethics?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --They do, Your Honor, and each of those regulations would be applicable to a public defender as well.
Where I would make the distinction between the hypothetical that you have posed would be the extent that the public domain does exercise control over the public defender.

In other words, it becomes involved in the political process through the funding, through the appointment, through the decision on whether or not to keep the office, through the reports that must be made to the supervisors on an annual basis, and et cetera.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If we hold that the defense counsel here is subject to the same rules as anybody else, and that he is liable for acting under color of state law, wouldn't we thereafter be obliged to give him the same immunity we give the prosecutor?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Why not?
That matter has been the subject of great debate in this Court and in many courts of appeal.
I would suggest to the Court that the policy considerations were carefully reviewed by this Court in 1979 in the case of Ferri versus Ackerman.
As this Court has questioned Mr. Jesse this morning, it was in fact a state malpractice action.
However, the Court's inquiry was directed to whether or not Federal law required the imposition of an absolute immunity for a private attorney who was appointed under the Criminal Justice Act.
This Court in reviewing the relevant policy considerations determined that the... a defense attorney's function is considerably different from that of a prosecutor or of a judge.

I would agree with the Chief Justice's comment that they are part of the three legs of a particular stool upon which justice rests, but the distinction must be that the defense attorney, unlike the judge or the prosecutor, owes his primary allegiance to his particular client.
In fact, it is the defense lawyer's obligation to vigorously oppose the actions of the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that everybody's pocketbook is secure except defense counsel.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Well, that is the point that is made in the dissent in the Eighth Circuit, Your Honor, that an aggrieved defendant will look to the public defender.
I don't agree with that particular philosophy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He is not usually the wealthiest man in the county.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, if a private attorney representing a criminal defendant on appeal concludes that the case is utterly frivolous, what is his duty?
A private attorney now.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: A private attorney?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: We have in Iowa, Your Honor, a rule that is modeled after this Court's decision in Anders versus California.
That is Rule 104, which is included in one on of the briefs as an appendix, I believe.
That rule, as I read it, is not applicable to the private attorney.
My response, I am afraid, would be that the private attorney should not have accepted the case in the beginning, and should have perhaps reviewed the case.
The appointed counsel finds himself in a different position, in that he has no choice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Before we come back to the appointed counsel, the private attorney, as you suggested, if he considered it was frivolous, would have the duty, I suppose, first of all to tell the client.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He also has a duty to the court, and what does that duty to the court embrace?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: The duty to the court, it would be my judgment, would include not pursuing frivolous appeals.
If the consent of the client could not be obtained, I would think that an application to withdraw from the case would be the appropriate response to that situation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And why do you think there is a difference?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Between the privately retained attorney--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Between the privately retained counsel and the public defender, who reaches the same conclusion, that the appeal is utterly frivolous.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --I believe this Court in Anders, Your Honor, recognized that there was a similar obligation, and you cannot unilaterally simply dismiss an appeal, or you cannot unilaterally withdraw from the case, but you must follow a procedure that was carefully delineated in Anders.
You have to notify the client.
You have to brief to the appellate court any issues that are at least arguable on their merits.
And--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: My assumption is that you find no legitimate arguable position.
You have a duty to the Court, I would think.
You are still a lawyer.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --I think you would still have the same duty.
Yes, Your Honor.
It seems to me the procedures must be somewhat different--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Perhaps.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --because Rule 104 does not include the hypothetical that you have posed, but still the obligation to the Court not to waste their time would include, it should seem to me, a procedure somewhat like that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If the private attorney, knowing the appeal was frivolous, did nothing, prosecuted it, and then sent the client a bill--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: The prosecutor, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --I am sorry.
Pursued the appeal.
A private attorney--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --concluded the appeal was frivolous, did not advise his client, went ahead and argued the case, lost it, of course, sent the client a bill.
Would that be malpractice?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: It is shabby lawyering, Your Honor.
I don't know if it would be--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It sure would.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --malpractice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do very many lawyers today, private or otherwise, want to take the risk of not pressing every claim that the defendant wants him to press, and every appeal that the defendant wants pressed?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: No, Your Honor, they don't.
Most lawyers practice somewhat defensively in the criminal law area.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They now have to protect their flanks from their own client.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, is the prosecutor totally without obligations to the defendant, the accused person?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Well, of course, this Court in Brady versus Maryland and other such similar decisions has--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, apart from that, in the first instance the prosecutor certainly has a professional obligation not to present evidence to a grand jury or to a petit jury later on trial which he does not regard as reliable.
That is one of the canons.
He has an obligation not to seek indictments against people unless there is a solid basis for it.

There are a whole range of obligations, limited, to be sure, compared with the defense counsel, but he is obliged to do certain things which are for the protection of the accused, or the putative accused.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --That is true, Your Honor.
The same is also true of the defense counsel.
There are limited circumstances where the defense counsel has... or at least should perform some act that may well be directly contrary to the best interests of his client.
Examples would include when a defense lawyer knows that his client is about to lie on the witness stand.
It is his obligation to bring that to the attention of the court.
If the defense lawyer knows that a serious crime is about to be committed, it also is imperative upon the lawyer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the defense lawyer who knows or believes his client is about to lie is directed by the standards not to do anything to help him other than letting him take the stand and tell the story in his own words.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but not to participate in the deception--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In any fraud on the part--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --not to attempt to elicit testimony from the witness.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Mr. Hudson, in this case, does the complaint allege that the lawyer, Ms. Shepard, did anything other than what a competent lawyer would do?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Other inconclusory language?
She apparently filed an Anders brief pursuant to Rule 104, and had the... moved to dismiss the appeal.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: That is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there any allegation in the complaint that the appeal would have had any merit had it not been dismissed?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --I believe there is such an allegation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I don't think there is.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Well, to say the very minimum, the complaint is inarticulate, Justice Stevens, and it is my--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It refers to the Eighth Amendment, but I don't think you would contend there is a violation of the Eighth Amendment alleged.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --He uses conclusory language to assert such a violation, but the underlying facts at least that are set forth in this--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't it like hundreds I have seen, that the main reason is, he was convicted?
And so, the only way he can be convicted was ineffective assistance of counsel.
Isn't that what it adds up to?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Well, I am not going to concede that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I have seen hundreds of them.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I would state to the Court that because of the procedural posture of this particular case, we know very little about the underlying merits.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see.
But if there is merit to the claim that there was a constitutional violation, is not the plaintiff entitled to his release from prison?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: That would be true as a habeas petition.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't it sort of strange to be suing for damages while you don't even challenge in the appropriate forum the conviction that keeps you there?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: He--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I take it there is no challenge, at least not before us.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Not before this Court today.
No, Your Honor, there is not.
He did include in the pro se complaint that was filed with Judge Vietor a request to be released from prison--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To be released, and to have the lawyer disbarred, and the judge said he wouldn't do either of those things.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --And the request to be released was treated as an application for habeas, and was denied on the ground that state remedies had not been exhausted, but in direct answer to your question--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It seems to me the whole litigation over the quality of his representation is premature before we know whether he is entitled to his release, because if he is not entitled to his release, he has suffered no damages.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Your Honor, the way that the case was procedurally handled, we don't know the merits of the underlying complaint.
No hearing was granted in the District Court.
You inquired of Mr. Jesse as to the Rule 104 procedure.
I don't find a clear answer to that in the record before this Court this morning... this afternoon, and you know, perhaps it is a matter of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think it would be appropriate to have a trial on this complaint without first having a trial on the question, first exhausting remedies and finding out whether the conviction is valid?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --It has never been the requirement of this Court since Monroe versus Pape that state remedies be exhausted prior to the prosecution of a Section 1983 complaint, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But how could, in a trial like this... Maybe that is true, but there has also never been a trial to my knowledge of a 1983 case against a defense lawyer while the defendant is still sitting in jail.
It just seems to me a rather--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I believe that is true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --It is a strange order in which to do business.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Well, it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because how would you compute damages if you figure he is still going to be there?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Well, the elements of this particular offense also have not been defined by any lower court, and I don't believe that the elements of this particular segment of Section 1983 are before the Court this afternoon, and so the computation of damages, I would suggest that we rely merely upon tort principles, as this Court has suggested.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it is rather clear that the plaintiff could not recover damages if he is lawfully incarcerated, isn't it?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I don't know if that is clear, Your Honor.
It would turn again upon relevant principles of tort law.
That would go, however, not to the... that would go to the question of damages, and not to the question--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But in order for him to prevail on the merits of his complaint, he must prove a constitutional violation, under 1983.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if he can prove a constitutional violation, a fortiori, his conviction is invalid.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that would be true.
What about the situation, however, where he could prove a constitutional violation that was deemed to be harmless error.
Under Section--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There are no damages for harmless error.
That is perfectly clear.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Under Section 1983, that may well be a compensable injury.
We must understand that the questions that you are raising with me right now go to the question of damages.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And whether the complaint has alleged a cause of action.
I am just wondering whether it is necessary to get into all this state action business when there is a lawsuit that is way, way ahead of schedule.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Well, the question before the Court is whether it does state a cause of action, and you make some very valid points, Your Honor, regarding damages, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But 1983 provides for damages.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --It does, and that is the basic purpose, Justice Marshal, of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the district judge perhaps on a proper motion could have dismissed this case on the... for lack of an allegation of the cause of action, because of the lack of a showing that he is improperly incarcerated.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --The district judge did dismiss it for failure to state a claim, finding that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, is there any reason why the district judge could not act on that?
That is the thrust of my question.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --For failure to state a--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, on the very grounds that have just been under discussion.
That he can't make out a case, he can't make out a case until some court has determined that the accused is unconstitutionally confined in a prison.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --Well, I would again reiterate my position, Your Honor, that it has never been the rule or the law under Section 1983 that prior state remedies must first be exhausted.
The Court is making reference, I believe, to a habeas action in the state courts of Iowa.
It has always been the rule since Monroe versus Pape that you can proceed directly to Federal court, and the purpose, in fact, of 1983 is to provide a Federal forum for compensation of injuries.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not if you are attacking... not if you are attacking your custody.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: We are not attacking the custody.
We want compensation for the constitutional violation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What was he sentenced for?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Robbery.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For how long?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Twenty-five years, I believe, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So he is still in prison?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was there an appeal that was never disposed of?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: There was an appeal which became the subject of this particular lawsuit, and I don't believe the record clearly reflects the disposition of that particular appeal.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, in the appeal, was the question of adequacy of counsel raised at all?

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: I don't believe that it was, Your Honor, because Mrs. Shepard represented him in that appeal, and she unlikely would raise that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, this lawsuit doesn't challenge the adequacy of representation by trial counsel, as I read the complaint.
It just challenges adequacy of representation by appellate counsel for filing and Anders brief.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is the gist of the lawsuit.

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: And not pursuing the appeal, Justice Stevens, for what Mr. Dodson believed--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's right.
He was asking for dismissal under Rule 104--

turn.speaker: john_d_hudson
turn.label: Mr. John D. Hudson
turn.text: --to be meritorious grounds.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Kneedler?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I will address the question whether a public defender employed by a county acts under color of state law within the meaning of 42 United States Code Section 1983, in the course... when he performs his official duties under state law of representing indigent defendants.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And what is the United States' interest in this, in arguing that particular question?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: This issue is of interest to the United States because the language in Section 1983 referring to color of law, color of statute is the precise language, is parallel to the language in Section 242 of Title 18, which provides criminal sanctions for anyone who willfully subjects a person to the deprivation of constitutional rights while acting under color of law, and this Court has construed the color of law language in Section 242 to be... Given it essentially the same scope as the color of law language in Title... in Section 1983.
In this case, the principal conduct complained of by Respondent was the alleged failure of Petitioner Shepard to adequately represent him on appeal of his state conviction.
Respondent further alleges that this inadequacy was due to or pursuant to policies adopted by the offender advocate and by... apparently by the Board of Supervisors of Polk County.
As described by Mr. Hudson, the county... the Polk County Offender Advocate's office is established pursuant to a state statute that calls for the establishment of county public defenders's offices.
In this case, the offender advocate was appointed by the Board of Supervisors, is entirely funded by the Board of Supervisors.
It seems clear, then, that the Polk County Offender Advocate's office is an agency of Polk County.
Indeed, the chapter of the Iowa Code that authorizes counties to establish offender advocates' offices is entitled county and township government.
So, acting pursuant to the state statute, the county has established an office of county government for the purpose of providing function... defense to indigent defendants.
Moreover, in this case, the conduct complained of was the inadequacy of Petitioner Shepard's representation of Respondent on appeal.

The relevant provisions of the Iowa statute expressly require the public defender, once he is appointed, to represent... to defend and counsel the defendant, and to represent him at all stages of his subsequent post-conviction remedies, including appeal or other remedies.

So, in this case the county employee involved, the assistant public defender, was discharging her duties under county ordinance and state law when she filed the Anders brief or the alleged Anders brief that Respondent complains of.

It would seem indisputable that a state employee, or the actions of a state employee undertaken in the course of the discharge of her official duties under state law is properly attributable to the state, and therefore would be state action for purposes of the Fourteenth Amendment.

Given this, it would seem equally indisputable that those same actions would be taken under color of state law for purposes of Section 1983, which was passed to enforce the restraints on state action imposed by the Fourteenth Amendment.

Indeed, this Court in United States versus Price said that in cases under Section 1983, the element of color of law has been treated as the same thing as the state action requirement for purposes of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about Section 242 and a private attorney, privately employed attorney, where it is held that there is state action involved if he misrepresents the... if the state continues to hold a person even though he has been misrepresented by... or badly represented?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: My understanding of the rationale of the Court's decision in Cuyler versus Sullivan was that the state action there involved was the fact that the state had deprived the defendant of his liberty pursuant to a judgment which was the culmination of a prosecution initiated by the state, and indeed the Court refers to the act, the state action as being the state's obtaining the conviction, which is tainted by the conduct of counsel.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think you have to, to win in this case, you have to show that the conduct of the public defender was pursuant to some rule of the county?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: No.
No, I do not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You just have to prove that he was an employee of the county?
Is that all?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And just given the general duties of representing indigents?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Yes, and I would like to follow up on that for a moment.

The notion, the argument that Petitioners seek to advance is that an exception should be carved out of the state action, or the color of law principle, because of the attorney-client relationship that is entered into between the public defender and the indigent defendant, the notion being that it is somehow antagonistic to the state when the public defender represents the indigent defendant.
I think that analysis is incorrect, and of course--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would it be incorrect with respect to the privately retained counsel?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, I think that presents quite a different question.
I think the reason why that is so--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, can you just say yes or no?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, we have not taken a position on whether there would be color of state law for anyone in this case, for anyone other than the state employed public defender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You haven't taken a position as to whether Section 242 would be applicable to a privately retained counsel.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: We have not to date.
That issue has not arisen.
But I would point out one distinction, I think, that is important in Cuyler, that might suggest... that at least would distinguish it from this case.

There are many actions or at least some actions by persons who everyone would concede are acting wholly in a private capacity which could nevertheless render a conviction invalid and unconstitutional, for instance, someone who might attempt to bribe a juror, or prejudicial publicity in a newspaper might render a trial... a conviction invalid under the Constitution because it deprived the defendant his right to a fair trial, but that would not necessarily render the private person acting under color of state law for these purposes.
But this case can be decided on a much narrower principle, that the defense counsel here was concededly an employee of the government.
What I was referring to earlier is that in a criminal trial, the government has two obligations, or two duties.
One is the duty of the prosecution to conduct a fair trial.
The second duty that evolves from the Court's decisions in Gideon and with respect to appeals from Anders, is to provide a defense.
provide for the Defendant to have a defense made on his behalf.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, if you rely on that argument, it would apply to appointed counsel as well as the public--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Not necessarily, because in--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Isn't it true that in your criminal prosecutions that raise a similar issue of lawyers, they have been public defenders who have used their office to get money out of indigent clients?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So there is a clear acting under color of state law in a way that is quite different from merely performing the office of lawyer in an incompetent manner.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, but in both events, the lawyer is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What I am suggesting is, those decisions are not necessarily implicated by what we do with this case.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, to an extent, I think they... to an extent, I think they are, because the fact, what is being... what is being discussed in this case, for example, is conduct that is at the very core of the person's duties under state law, and the state has imposed those duties, the relevant provisions of Iowa law expressly require as would seem implicit in the creation of the public defender's office, for the public defender to represent the defendant.

So, at the same time that he is performing his duty to his client, he is at the same time performing a duty... fulfilling his duty to the state in the creation of the public defender's office, so there is nothing inconsistent in saying that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I assume that if defense counsel gets a man acquitted, that helps the state.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Yes, the interests of justice are served if--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is not what I said.
I said, it helps the state.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is the presumption, at least, isn't it?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Yes, sir, it helps the state in the broadest sense, I would suppose, in seeing that justice is done, but here referring to the state as the government, the state would have been fulfilling its obligation of providing defense counsel.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about on the underlying question here, at least as I see one of the underlying questions?
What if a privately retained lawyer for an affluent client did precisely what Ms. Shepard did in this case?
Would there be any problems or liabilities or whatever?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, I suppose that... of course, this goes to the question of whether there was a constitutional violation rather than whether the counsel had acted under color of state law, but that, I think, would go back to the theory of Anders, whether... the obligation of counsel to file an Anders brief, and that has been... that could either be a due process right, in which case it would apply to private counsel, or an equal protection right ensuring indigent clients the same rights, and in that case it may not.
So I think it would depend on one's view of the theory of Anders itself.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, let's assume, not the... not the precise conduct here, but the defense counsel privately retained by an affluent client, said to his client, you have no case, you can't get anywhere on appeal, and I won't put my name on any appeal except to protect you by filing the notice of appeal, and then I am out, you get yourself another lawyer.
Any problem on the underlying question there?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: On whether there has been a constitutional violation?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On whether there is any liability as between them, laying aside the constitutional question.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, I would think that there would be a liability exposure under state malpractice law, depending on--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean a lawyer can't withdraw from a case?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Oh, he could withdraw, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what I meant.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: I am sorry.
Yes.
No, if he withdrew, I would... whether or not the Constitution requires it, it would certainly be proper to follow the same type of procedure as in Anders.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
You have one minute remaining.

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, the Respondent and the United States, and the United States in particular with concern... with respect to their ability to file Section 242 criminal prosecutions, would have the Court look no further than the kind of instrumentality argument about whether or not the county has established a public defender program, irrespective of what the real actions are, and they point out that... that the Petitioners have not referred to the case of United States versus Classic, but Unites States versus Classic does tell us that the activity that is aimed at in 1983 actions is the misuse of power possessed by virtue of state law and made possible only because the wrongdoer is cloaked with the authority of state law--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, Classic involved the whole state of Louisiana, didn't it?

turn.speaker: norman_g_jesse
turn.label: Mr. Norman G. Jesse
turn.text: --Yes, but in this particular, what I am suggesting is that we ought to look at the activity, and not merely that it is an instrumentality, because it is the activity that is important, and that activity is not.
It's the representation, and that does not depend upon the creation of the public defender, but is the result of being licensed to practice law, as is true of every lawyer.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
